displayed_text: Family Member 1: No. But we knew this. We knew that the first line of drugs wasn’t going to last forever and we were going to have to go to a new line of drugs. And when this doesn’t work, we’ll go to the next line. We, you’ve been very honest about that since day one that that this is how it was going to go. Doctor: And you told me you’re holding your own so you’re hanging right in there. Family Member 1: Right. Doctor: You’re still better than when you started. Right? Patient: Yeah. Huh, you said it, well, it’s a concern from one to three hundred and fifty. But you said from the beginning you don’t want it to go over six hundred. Family Member 1: No one said that. Family Member: No. Patient: Yeah. I remember him saying that. Doctor: Yeah. I wouldn’t say that. There’s no number that, huh, I can tell you there’s no number that I get excited about. Family Member 1: He said if the number went up too many times, he would check the scans because he doesn’t go by the number. The number just shows that that medicine wasn’t necessary. Patient: I wonder how long I’ve had this damn cancer. Doctor: And you get your blood work Quest LabCorp here?

Family Member: Not ‘til the biopsy. Doctor: …plan would be maybe two weeks or three weeks from today. Patient: And that would be after the biopsy? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Uh… Family Member: Any other tests that we need to know about? Blood work and bone biopsy? Doctor: That’s all what I can think of right now. Healthcare Professional: and recent scans. Doctor: Yeah the scans are pretty recent so we should be able to use those. Family Member: With this – so with this new regime would he get the CAT scan bone scan and stuff sooner than six months?
DOC Probably oh yeah, yes. Definitely sooner than six months. It’s between eight to twelve weeks. And that’s all in this protocol we’re gonna read? And is that still N__ or R__ or no more N__ or R__ … Doctor: Well they will be from here so she will bring you the copy of the consent. Today you’re just taking the copy to read. But uh no then it will be S__ is the downtown person. I think you may have met her. Family Member: We met S___, yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and then you randomize it. In other words, you flip a coin. You give half of them a specified dose of Metformin and you give the other half a placebo immunotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then at the end of the day you look at the outcomes and you see are the recurrence rates you know slowed down less in the patients that receive the Metformin or alternatively our prevention rates that with time those that don’t receive the Metformin. The - the type of studies that have suggested that Metformin is beneficial, the so-called epidemiological studies. In other words, given the retrospectives, where they take a series of patients – Patient: Got it. Doctor: - and they go back and ask them based on questionnaires Were you taking Metformin and when did you start and how long? What was the reason for being on it? Patient: Yes.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But everybody's on the second pill at the right dose, and the Xtandi. ‘ Patient: Okay, I think I understand that. Okay. Doctor: Yes. And if you try to look on the internet, it's not the way it is, they just literally opened this up. So when M____, who was one that was calling you, she just wanted to know if you are even interested. Because if so we would have to get a spot. And then when you come in, you see a W____ equivalent, but just somebody who knows that study better. Kind of like a M____ and a W____hybrid. And you would be seen across the hall in our other area, but you still have me you can't get rid of me. And then we just decide if this is the right thing or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The alternative would be you know, let's say you're not eligible or you're not interested, we would try a different study to see; we would get off that Xtandi and try something else. I just said, “Well you are already on the 80 maybe we can get this guy come back and do more.” So that's an option, but there are still more options. So I don't want you to worry if that one is not going to work or is not appealing. We got more options. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Questions. Patient: Well, the first question is of course- Doctor: Yep. Patient: -is side effects. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I haven't gotten, gotten down to that.

Patient: …this is what J____ takes every single day. Doctor: Yes so then we know. Patient: And I’m very religious about it. Doctor: The other part now is sort of what do we do? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So let’s say we gather this information, we’re biopsying terrific, uh you know it’s all good for lab stuff, but what are we doing to actually treat it? There are several options. One, pills. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: So either Xtandi or Zytiga is actually they’re both FDA approved in this space… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …to treat folks who have progressed, albeit gently for you, a few new things and a few a little bit of a rise on the PSA, but enough to show that you need to be on something. Both equally good. Both equally have their own pot of side effects. Both equally effective in lowering the PSA and treating the cancer. Patient: Just so you know… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …of all the treatments I’ve had…

Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic. Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case.

Patient: I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Yeah. What’s new? Patient: Nothing. Doctor: Nothing. Is this one giving you trouble? Doctor: She gives me trouble. I’m glad you qualified. We’re just waiting on the paperwork. patients. Family Member: You can talk. I’m just talking with a patient. Doctor: Didn’t mean to interrupt you. Doctor: The light’s going to stay on? Family Member: She’s upstairs. Doctor: New patient? Family Member: Yep. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Wait at the desk and enjoy the rest of the year. I’ll see you in the early part of next year. Okay? Patient: Alright. Alright. Thank you, Dr. P___, so much. Doctor: No problem. Alright. Very good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know how to find your way out? Patient: Yes Sir. Doctor: Okay. Down the hall to the left, this way, turn left and Healthcare Professional 2: Are you okay? Patient: Does she still need me?

Patient: Oh out here? Doctor: No or when you go over for treatment you can hand it to your nurse Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they can make all the schedule for you. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So you don’t have to wait here. Patient: Right. Doctor: Yeah. (mumbling to herself) Patient: Uh I didn’t know Lupron I I guess so. Doctor: Yeah. Mhmm. Now, do you want me to uh so what prescriptions do you need me to send? Patient: The… Doctor: The prednisone once a day. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right now it must be boiling down there. Michigan is pleasant. Patient: Yeah compared to Kentucky, yes. Doctor: So next week I’m thinking if we get you authorized for this Firmagon injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay I can always cancel if I don’t need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we need to uh see if the testosterone is not right then I need… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …to get that authorized. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if the majority of your Gleason pattern is higher than tree, and the small minority is higher than four, since you have more of the four and less then the three to more Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you are a lot more than then they’re gonna Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So you have an intermediate risk, but potentially . Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which actually will be sort of . So if you feel comfortable continuing with the next step, the next step will be for me to get a Patient: Okay. Yeah I’m interested uh huh so if the next step is I’ll read this and I’ll talk to my wife and my children and I’ve basically tell them this is the route that I wanted to go as far as radiation. I mean you’ve given me enough information with the random selection- Doctor: Correct. Patient: so I understand. My biggest concern is around the randmon selection is how long I’ll remain in that before actually having… Doctor: Right, now one thing to say about that and this is true of every clinical trial, you have the option to if you don’t want to.

Patient: doctor Doctor: Hey, how are ya? I’m going to just go through a couple of questions with you. Family Member: Ok. Doctor: Catch things up. Patient: Alright. Doctor: No new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: Uh, the medicines that you take. You’re on – I thought you’re taking your, uh, apixaban or Eliquis? Five milligrams? Patient: Right. Doctor: You take that once a day, twice a day? Patient: Twice a day uh. Once in the morning and once at night. (Pause) Doctor: And then bupropion or Wellbutrin a hundred and fifty milligrams a day? Or twice a day? Patient: Twice, uh, I think they are seventy milligrams twice a day.

Patient: Okay. Now, so, along with what we’ve talked about, if we decide that, uh, uh, the, uh, the clinical trial is not working- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Then, what I’m going to do is go back to K___? And so J___ H___ will not be involved anymore after that? Doctor: So let’s talk about that for a second. So there are two main options. One is that if you wanted to pursue a standard therapy, such as enzalutamide, also called Xtandi, or chemotherapy, that would be through K___, because as a standard therapy, you will not have privileges, unless you paid out of pocket, to come here for that therapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: On the other hand, the second possibility is to participate in a different clinical trial. So I’ll give you one example. So we have a trial right now testing immunotherapy against prostate cancer. That is a drug that stimulates your own immune system to hopefully fight and kill the cancer. Okay? That’s just one example. We might have at least one more trial that you’re also eligible for. But both of these trials would not really rely on that mutation, specifically, but they are just trials that you would still qualify for, uh, independent of the mutation. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If you decided to participate in a different clinical trial, then, of course, you could receive that therapy here as long as K___ approved of you to enroll in that trial, which they probably will, because their general policy is if you’re participating in a trial at an institution that’s not available through K___, then they support that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you could definitely still be our patient, and we would love it if you were. Uh, we’ve gotten to know you for the past several months, and I think your experience with us has also been relatively good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so, you know, that could be a win-win, but we have to make sure that it’s something that makes sense for you. We’re not going to put you on a trial just for the sake of keeping you at H___.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: …and sort of prevent further damage. Patient: Right. Doctor: At least first of all maybe give your nerves a chance to recover at least it prevents total further loss of - Patient: Right. Doctor: -strength and all that. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this what <___> I’m talking about so… Patient: Well I have an appointment with him next week. Doctor: The arms and hands are not something you can… Patient: No, no. Doctor: …get by easily without chuckles]].

Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: But, it’s usually letters and numbers. Ummm. But, they work in a class of drugs that we think are highly active in prostate cancer, so it’s about five different drugs that are in this space, targeting the same pathway. So, we just don’t know which one has an opening. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And, when would that start? Doctor: M___ will tell us, but probably, you know, obviously in the new year, and it maybe second or third week… Patient: Well, they took seven vials of blood… Doctor: Yes, we did! Patient: Three of them are staying here… Doctor: Mm-hmm. Patient: And we should get the results shortly. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And the other four were going back to the lab, or to the ….
